repnme.cdata!: Rwanda - Special Emergency Assistance Grant Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Special Emergency
            Assistance Grant Project for Rwanda were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, project sustainability was
            likely, Bank performance was satisfactory and implementing
            agencies performance for United Nations Children's Fund
            (UNICEF), United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
            (UNHCR), Food and Agricultural Organization of the United
            Nations (FAO), and World Health Organization (WHO) was
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the grant
            proved to be an effective mechanism for the Bank to
            intervene in a situation where its normal tools will not
            have responded in time, and emergency grant helped to lay
            the basis for Bank direct intervention. It is important in
            these situations to appraise the Government of the nature of
            the type of operation and have it involved where practicable
            to dispel possible dissatisfaction by the government in
            being by-passed. It will be essential, in grant operations,
            to stipulate the procedures for the disposal of all major
            equipment and vehicles purchased through the proceeds of the
            grant in the legal agreements to minimize misunderstandings.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency Recovery
            Credit (ECR) Project for Rwanda were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, project sustainability was uncertain,
            Bank performance was satisfactory and Borrower performance
            was also a satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the
            design of emergency operations should be kept simple, and
            particularly avoid operational conditions for effectiveness.
            Conditions that are essential for the operation of the
            credit should be conditions for board presentation. It is
            important to gauge the government's capacity and
            commitment, in order to design an operation that responds
            effectively the realities in the country. Deep understanding
            of politically sensitive issues by the Bank, and
            International Development Association (IDA) and donor
            procedures by the Borrower, are important for the Bank and
            the Borrower to understand each other and work well
            together. The ECR served as a catalyst for providing funding
            for the reconstruction of Rwanda and encouraged
            burden-sharing among donors. As such, it represented an
            important part of a broad-based international rescue effort;
            however, there was a lack of coordinated effort to raise the
            additional resources required for an effective recovery program.

18154259.theme: Other rural development,Health system performance,Education for all,Conflict prevention and post-conflict reconstruction,Other financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Recovery Credit Project is
            designed to: 1) help the government begin the restoration of
            key economic and social services, rebuild the institutional
            capacity necessary for sustainable economic recovery and
            design a coherent economic policy framework; and 2) provide
            the private sector with the means to resume operations and
            create jobs. The project's components support imports
            by the government and the private sector of high priority
            items on a broad positive list, and technical assistance to
            help implement reconstruction and re-establish basic
            government functions. Eligible imports will include spare
            parts, inputs and capital equipment in priority sectors such
            as: agriculture, industry, transportation, energy, water and
            sanitation, education and health.
